standard_metadata.standard_description: Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm for each operation.

question.content: **Which of the following expressions is equivalent to $0.034 \times 4.8$?**

hints.content: Let's rewrite the decimals in fraction form. Then we can use the properties of multiplication to write an equivalent expression.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{0.034} \times \maroonD{4.8} &= \blueE{\dfrac{34}{1{,}000}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{48}{10}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{34 \times \dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{48 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \end{align}$  We are multiplying, so we can use the commutative and associative properties. Let's rearrange and group the fractions.

$\begin{align} \blueE{0.034} \times \maroonD{4.8} &= \blueE{\dfrac{34}{1{,}000}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{48}{10}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{34 \times \dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{48 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{34}  \times \maroonD{48} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &={34}  \times {48} \times {\dfrac{1}{10{,}000}}  \end{align}$
The expression $34\times 48 \times \dfrac{1}{10{,}000}$ is equivalent to $0.034 \times 4.8$.

question.content: **Which of the following expressions is equivalent to $2.3 \times 5.01$?**

hints.content: Let's rewrite the decimals in fraction form. Then we can use the properties of multiplication to write an equivalent expression.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{2.3} \times \maroonD{5.01} &= \blueE{\dfrac{23}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{501}{100}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{23 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{501 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right) \end{align}$  We are multiplying, so we can use the commutative and associative properties. Let's rearrange and group the fractions.

$\begin{align} \blueE{2.3} \times \maroonD{5.01} &= \blueE{\dfrac{23}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{501}{100}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{23 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{501 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{23}  \times \maroonD{501} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{100}}\right)\\\\ &={23}  \times {501} \times {\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}  \end{align}$
The expression $23\times 501 \times \dfrac{1}{1{,}000}$ is equivalent to $2.3 \times 5.01$.

question.content: **Which of the following expressions is equivalent to $5.9 \times 8.7$?**

hints.content: Let's rewrite the decimals in fraction form. Then we can use the properties of multiplication to write an equivalent expression.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{5.9} \times \maroonD{8.7} &= \blueE{\dfrac{59}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{87}{10}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{59 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{87 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \end{align}$  We are multiplying, so we can use the commutative and associative properties. Let's rearrange and group the fractions.

$\begin{align} \blueE{5.9} \times \maroonD{8.7} &= \blueE{\dfrac{59}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{87}{10}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{59 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{87 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{59}  \times \maroonD{87} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &={59}  \times {87} \times {\dfrac{1}{100}}  \end{align}$
The expression $59\times 87 \times \dfrac{1}{100}$ is equivalent to $5.9 \times 8.7$.

question.content: **Which of the following expressions is equivalent to $4.11 \times 0.055$?**

hints.content: Let's rewrite the decimals in fraction form. Then we can use the properties of multiplication to write an equivalent expression.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{4.11} \times \maroonD{0.055} &= \blueE{\dfrac{411}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{55}{1{,}000}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{411 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{55 \times \dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}\right) \end{align}$  We are multiplying, so we can use the commutative and associative properties. Let's rearrange and group the fractions.

$\begin{align} \blueE{4.11} \times \maroonD{0.055} &= \blueE{\dfrac{411}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{55}{1{,}000}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{411 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{55 \times \dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{411}  \times \maroonD{55} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}\right)\\\\ &={411}  \times {55} \times {\dfrac{1}{100{,}000}}  \end{align}$
The expression $411\times 55 \times \dfrac{1}{100{,}000}$ is equivalent to $4.11 \times 0.055$.

question.content: **Which of the following expressions is equivalent to $0.12 \times 0.7$?**

hints.content: Let's rewrite the decimals in fraction form. Then we can use the properties of multiplication to write an equivalent expression.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{0.12} \times \maroonD{0.7} &= \blueE{\dfrac{12}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{10}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{12 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{7 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \end{align}$  We are multiplying, so we can use the commutative and associative properties. Let's rearrange and group the fractions.

$\begin{align} \blueE{0.12} \times \maroonD{0.7} &= \blueE{\dfrac{12}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{10}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{12 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{7 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{12}  \times \maroonD{7} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &={12}  \times {7} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}  \end{align}$  The numbers $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}$ and $\goldE{1{,}000}$ are reciprocals of each other. So *multiplying* by $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}$ is the same as *dividing* by $\goldE{1{,}000}$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{0.12} \times \maroonD{0.7} &= \blueE{\dfrac{12}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{10}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{12 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{7 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{12}  \times \maroonD{7} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &={12}  \times {7} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}  \\\\ &= 12\times 7 \div \goldE{1{,}000} \end{align}$
The expression $12\times 7 \div \goldE{1{,}000}$ is equivalent to $0.12 \times 0.7$.

question.content: **Which of the following expressions is equivalent to $106 \times 3.7$?**

hints.content: Let's rewrite the decimals in fraction form. Then we can use the properties of multiplication to write an equivalent expression.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{106} \times \maroonD{3.7} &= \blueE{106} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{37}{10}}\\\\ &=\blueE{106} \times \left(\maroonD{37 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \end{align}$  We are multiplying, so we can use the commutative and associative properties. Let's rearrange and group the fractions.

$\begin{align} \blueE{106} \times \maroonD{3.7} &= \blueE{106} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{37}{10}}\\\\ &=\blueE{106} \times \left(\maroonD{37 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &={106} \times {37} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{10}} \end{align}$  The numbers $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ and $\goldE{10}$ are reciprocals of each other. So *multiplying* by $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ is the same as *dividing* by $\goldE{10}$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{106} \times \maroonD{3.7} &= \blueE{106} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{37}{10}}\\\\ &=\blueE{106} \times \left(\maroonD{37 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &={106}  \times {37} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\\\\ &= 106\times 37 \div \goldE{10} \end{align}$
The expression $106\times 37 \div \goldE{10}$ is equivalent to $106 \times 3.7$.

question.content: **Which of the following expressions is equivalent to $0.8 \times 12.4$?**

hints.content: Let's rewrite the decimals in fraction form. Then we can use the properties of multiplication to write an equivalent expression.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{0.8} \times \maroonD{12.4} &= \blueE{\dfrac{8}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{124}{10}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{8 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{124 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \end{align}$  We are multiplying, so we can use the commutative and associative properties. Let's rearrange and group the fractions.

$\begin{align} \blueE{0.8} \times \maroonD{12.4} &= \blueE{\dfrac{8}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{124}{10}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{8 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{124 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{8}  \times \maroonD{124} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &={8}  \times {124} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{100}}  \end{align}$  The numbers $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{100}}$ and $\goldE{100}$ are reciprocals of each other. So *multiplying* by $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{100}}$ is the same as *dividing* by $\goldE{100}$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{0.8} \times \maroonD{12.4} &= \blueE{\dfrac{8}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{124}{10}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{8 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{124 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{8}  \times \maroonD{124} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &={8}  \times {124} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{100}} \\\\ &= 8\times 124 \div \goldE{100} \end{align}$
The expression $8\times 124 \div \goldE{100}$ is equivalent to $0.8 \times 12.4$.

question.content: **Which of the following expressions is equivalent to $4.56 \times 0.031$?**

hints.content: Let's rewrite the decimals in fraction form. Then we can use the properties of multiplication to write an equivalent expression.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{4.56} \times \maroonD{0.031} &= \blueE{\dfrac{456}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{31}{1{,}000}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{456 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{31 \times \dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}\right) \end{align}$  We are multiplying, so we can use the commutative and associative properties. Let's rearrange and group the fractions.

$\begin{align} \blueE{4.56} \times \maroonD{0.031} &= \blueE{\dfrac{456}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{31}{1{,}000}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{456 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{31 \times \dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{456}  \times \maroonD{31} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}\right)\\\\ &={456}  \times {31} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{100{,}000}} \end{align}$  The numbers $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{100{,}000}}$ and $\goldE{100{,}000}$ are reciprocals of each other. So *multiplying* by $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{100{,}000}}$ is the same as *dividing* by $\goldE{100{,}000}$.

$\begin{align} \blueE{4.56} \times \maroonD{0.031} &= \blueE{\dfrac{456}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{31}{1{,}000}}\\\\ &=\left(\blueE{456 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{31 \times \dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{456}  \times \maroonD{31} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}\right)\\\\ &={456}  \times {31} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{100{,}000}} \\\\ &= 456\times 31 \div \goldE{100{,}000} \end{align}$
The expression $456\times 31 \div \goldE{100{,}000}$ is equivalent to $4.56 \times 0.031$.

question.content: The product $796 \times 68$ equals $54{,}128$.  **Use the previous fact to evaluate as a decimal.**  $7.96 \times 6.8 = $

hints.content: Instead of $796\times 68$, the second product is $796\,\text{hundredths} \times 68\,\text{tenths}$.  We can group the fraction factors to see how the second product relates to the first product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{7.96} \times \maroonD{6.8} &=\left(\blueE{796 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{68 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{796}  \times \maroonD{68} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{100}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\goldE{796 \times 68} \times {\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}  \end{align}$  We already know the value of $\goldE{796 \times 68}$.
$\begin{align} \blueE{7.96} \times \maroonD{6.8} &={\dfrac{\goldE{54{,}128}}{1{,}000}}  \end{align}$  To divide $\goldE{54{,}128}$ by $1{,}000$, we shift every digit $3$ places to the right.

question.content: The product $97 \times 8$ equals $776$.  **Use the previous fact to evaluate as a decimal.**  $9.7 \times 0.08 = $

hints.content: Instead of $97\times 8$, the second product is $97\,\text{tenths} \times 8\,\text{hundredths}$.  We can group the fraction factors to see how the second product relates to the first product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{9.7} \times \maroonD{0.08} &=\left(\blueE{97 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{8 \times \dfrac{1}{100}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{97}  \times \maroonD{8} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{100}}\right)\\\\ &=\goldE{97 \times 8} \times {\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}}  \end{align}$  We already know the value of $\goldE{97 \times 8}$.
$\begin{align} \blueE{9.7} \times \maroonD{0.08} &={\dfrac{\goldE{776}}{1{,}000}}  \end{align}$  To divide $\goldE{776}$ by $1{,}000$, we shift every digit $3$ places to the right.

question.content: The product $89 \times 76$ equals $6{,}764$.  **Use the previous fact to evaluate as a decimal.**  $89 \times 7.6 = $

hints.content: Instead of $89 \times 76$, the second product is $89 \times 76\,\text{tenths}$.  We can group the fraction factors to see how the second product relates to the first product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{89} \times \maroonD{7.6} &=\blueE{89} \times \left(\maroonD{76 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\goldE{89 \times 76} \times {\dfrac{1}{10}}  \end{align}$  We already know the value of $\goldE{89 \times 76}$.
$\begin{align} \blueE{89} \times \maroonD{7.6} &={\dfrac{\goldE{6{,}764}}{10}}  \end{align}$  To divide $\goldE{6{,}764}$ by $10$, we shift every digit $1$ place to the right.

question.content: The product $178 \times 86$ equals $15{,}308$.  **Use the previous fact to evaluate as a decimal.**  $17.8 \times 8.6 = $

hints.content: Instead of $178\times 86$, the second product is $178\,\text{tenths} \times 86\,\text{tenths}$.  We can group the fraction factors to see how the second product relates to the first product.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{17.8} \times \maroonD{8.6} &=\left(\blueE{178 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right) \times \left(\maroonD{86 \times \dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\blueE{178}  \times \maroonD{86} \times \left(\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\right)\\\\ &=\goldE{178 \times 86} \times {\dfrac{1}{100}}  \end{align}$  We already know the value of $\goldE{178 \times 86}$.
$\begin{align} \blueE{17.8} \times \maroonD{8.6} &={\dfrac{\goldE{15{,}308}}{100}}  \end{align}$  To divide $\goldE{15{,}308}$ by $100$, we shift every digit $2$ places to the right.
